Oxycodone was first synthesized in 1917. It became a huge health crisis in Germany in the late 1920s until it became a prescription-only-medication although Aldolf Hitler apparently injected oxycodone (brand name Eukadol) from late 1941 until 1945.  Then in 1950 Percodan & Percoset were introduced into the US. Each tablet only contained 5mg of oxycodone but since a person could be prescribed up to 8 tablets of either one per day, that allowed doctor shopping to provide a total of 80mg of oxycodone per day. By the 1980s it was a major killer within certain circles.  So the Sackler family had access to over 8 decades of warnings including tens of thousands of autopsies that showed abusers WERE taking large doses.  With that in mind they then chose to produce a formulation that allowed up to 160mg PER TABLET.  Oxycodone is synthetically simple being made from codeine or thebaine, both natural compounds found in certain species of poppy. It's hard to find bulk prices but Pharmacompass gives prices between $3500-$9500/Kg.  Even given the higher price, when you consider that people are apparently prepared to pay up to $1/mg, it doesn't take a genius to work out that a sophisticated criminal enterprise could produce very accurate imitations. Now generic versions of Oxycontin are available, as long as it comes as a tablet packaged in blister packs themselves placed within boxes, that $9500 becomes $1 million.  In fact, it's very likely to be MORE profitable than fentanyl BECAUSE people are prepared to pay so much more for it.

It is very important to note that on 16th Dec, 2021 a Federal Judge, Colleen McMahon of the US District Court for the Southern District of New York, overturned the bankruptcy settlement talked about in the video. She claimed that the original judge, Robert Drain, did not have the authority to grant immunity from personal liability. Whilst this decision will be appealed and the case will undoubtedly end up in the Supreme Court, it does mean that individual family members cannot be shielded from prosecution via bankruptcy. The actual judgement is available on the web and makes for fascinating reading. I guess that there will be an Opiod IV coming soon.
So some good news. While the bankruptcy court did agree to their deal, a federal judge tossed that shit out.

John Oliver, I hope you read this.  Another possible reason for the Opioid crisis is the suppression of medical research and ignorance towards the origins of pain.  There is solid research that pinpoints that the origins of ALL pain begins with the inflammatory process response in the body.  Here is an excerpt from an article (Irrespective of the characteristic of the pain, whether it is sharp, dull, aching, burning, stabbing, numbing or tingling, all pain arise from inflammation and the inflammatory response. We are proposing a re-classification and treatment of pain syndromes based upon their inflammatory profile.)  One of the best and most effective treatments is a long-acting, non-addictive injectable drug called TORADOL. Why on earth it is not being used post-operative, post-injury, or for acute short-term pain, and nerve pain confounds me.  Of course it is not a drug that can be used in every situation, but it has a broad range of use with a far lower chance of mortality.  My personal experience was falling off a roof cutting down branches. I landed  on a ladder. I was diagnosed with a cracked rib and severe contusions to my spine, pelvis, ribs, organs, muscles, nerves, tendons and ligaments. The pain was so severe that I was almost in constant tears.  My doctor immediately started me on a once a day 60mg injection of Toradol. By the 4th day I was 80% out of pain. We did discuss prescribing an opioid, but only if I didn't respond to the Toradol injections.  It was like magic. Toradol not only relieves pain, but it also heals; something opioids can't do. To my point is that there is this other cog in the wheel of this opioid addiction crisis - the suppression of pain research and financial support to advance current access. If states are going to fund drug rehab clinics, then why not fund pain control clinics or produce take home injectable like they have with insulin pens and hormone treatments or fertility drugs? As a nurse and my mom (also a nurse), the number one reason most doctors don't prescribe and administer drugs like Toradol, which are a lot safer and more effective without fear of addiction .........drum roll............. lazy. Just plain lazy. They rather call in to a pharmacy a months supply so they don't have to deal with the patient for a while.

"who doesn't get the .com?"   people who understand the actual purpose and intent of Top Level Domain (TLD) names.   The ‚Äúcom‚Äù in the .com domain name is for ‚Äúcommercial‚Äù sites, meaning business websites or websites that want to make money online. The .org is intended for use by nonprofit organizations.  The .net was designed for the internet, networking, and email service providers. And .info is meant for - you guessed it - websites or services providing 'information'.    So while the Sacklers  *are*  scum of the earth, their IT people still made the right choice in Top Level Domains.  Just be thankful they didn't use .club or .bargains, recent additions to the TLD list.  :P

The "opioid epidemic" is caused by people using illicit substances, NOT people using legitimate prescription pain medication.  The CDC 2016 Opioid Prescribing Guidelines state that prescription opioid pain medication is only 1% addictive, the AMA wants the CDC to retract those prescribing guidelines because they harm patients, the NIH has stated most overdoses are NOT caused by prescription pain meds, the DEA has been caught on many occasions diverting prescription medication to the black market, and the result of this whole thing is that millions of Americans who have painful chronic conditions are being denied medication that had given them some quality of life, end stage cancer patients are being denied pain medication because they "might become addicted," post-op patients who have overwhelmingly never had a problem with pain medication are now being denied it and told to take Tylenol (even though the amount required to equal the pain relief of an opioid would cause liver damage). This is opioid hysteria.  These companies are being run into bankruptcy and/or shutting down, and the DEA telling the rest to cut back on production is putting us in a very dangerous position of being short any pain medication.  Pretty soon everyone will be forced to recover from surgery without any pain meds, people with chronic pain will be told to do yoga and take a bottle of Advil every day to stop their joints or their skin from feeling like they're on fire.  Absolute nonsense and stupidity.  Go look up #dontpunishpain and other chronic pain tags and groups online, you'll find that there are many many thousands of people online who are suffering in agony because doctors are turning them away.  Example, my wife has a genetic connective tissue disorder that causes constant joint dislocations and has left her in misery.  Her pain management doctor decided one day he was no longer going to treat her because he did not want to go to jail.  She's now bedridden and talks of "ending it" because we cannot find ANY doctor to treat her and she doesn't know how much longer she can go on with unbearable pain. @john_oliver, I challenge you to look at the other side of the "opioid crisis," the one where so many people are now suffering from lack of proper pain treatment due to the stupid reporting that this is all the fault of prescription pain medication.

There are serious problems that come with a system getting too far out of whack.  The root problem has nothing to do with Opioids, OxyContin, or the Sacklers; it's that we have 2 completely separate legal systems.  One for the very wealthy, and one for everyone else (even the kinda wealthy).  _IF_ you are extremely wealthy you are immune to nearly all legal consequences.  I mean yeah, you can't go to times square and start shooting people and get away with it... but if you did, I bet you'd get a lighter sentence if you have a few billion in the bank.  So here is the problem with that; our Justice system only works as long as people believe in it and respect it.  Incidents like this shred that respect.  What that means is that people will stop taking civil recourse to the law, and some mother out of her mind with grief is going to shoot someone like a Sackler in the face.  I am not advocating violence, but once the wealthy start fucking people over with impunity and legal immunity, people will take 'justice' into their own hands and some of these wealthy assholes are going to turn up dead.  I am not saying that is what should happen, and I am not encouraging violence, I want to be very clear.  What I am doing is PREDICTING it's inevitability as the system gets tilted more and more in favor of the wealthy.  People will not respect courts, people will not use recourse to the law to settle disputes.  Our very well armed nation will start seeking it's own justice.  No body wants that.  Not the Sacklers, the victims' families, not the judges brokering these deals.... this is playing with fire, and everyone involved can get burned.  This is how judges, attorneys and billionaires start showing up dead.  It's happened in other countries once 'Justice' is proven to be a myth.  It's the natural reaction.  If justice is denied to you, revenge starts looking better.  We really don't want to go down this road, the courts need to stop being so obvious in their favoritism of the rich.  Once the illusion of justice in fair courts is shattered, people start to think about how to right wrongs in different ways.  We really don't want that.  I would argue in private to the Judge in White Plains that for the good of Justice itself, the preservation of the illusion at least, the Sacklers might need to be sacrificed.  Not a legal argument, a simple big picture argument.  What are the consequences of letting them get away scot free?  Think it through, think beyond this one case and whatever they are paying you (oh I am sure the bribes are well hidden, but there is obviously a reason this judge was chosen, even if he isn't on the take, he's still dirty or he wouldn't have been hand picked by the Sacklers).  Don't take my word for it, look at history when belief in justice breaks down in a society.  There are no happy destinations if we go down this road.  Full stop, back up.  We need to restore some balance here before the system collapses.  There even larger issues in play here beyond the fortunes of the Sackler family.  Every now and again, a billionaire who broke the law badly needs to get well and truly fucked by the courts.  An example, a sacrifice for the sake of illusion... actual justice... call it what you want.  But people need to believe even a billionaire can get in trouble if they break too serious of laws.  Too many Sacklers skate in this country?  The whole system can collapse.  Everyone involved in this needs to take a big step back and give a deep think to the consequences of yet another group of billionaires getting away with murder.  How many times can this happen before people go vigilante instead?  I feel like our legal system is on a precipice and no one wants to talk about the elephant in the room; our 2 court systems based on wealth.

So much of this is bullshit. The drugs themselves are safe since less than 3-5% of chronic pain patients misuse these medications, & significantly less will develop opioid use disorder from their rx. The people who developed opioid use disorder after taking oxycodone or oxycotin either had pre-existing substance abuse issues (including alcohol & nicotine) or used the medications at WAYYYY above therapeutic doses. Only street opioids are "highly addictive" since they aren't manufactured by pharmaceutical companies & often have varying amounts of fentanyl in them, making them impossible to assume a therapeutic/survivable dose to get high from, thereby causing addiction & overdoses. (Illicit opioids are taken for many reasons including for chronic pain & mental health issues that opioids are therapy for since they are nearly impossible to get rxd legally now, so even when used at therapeutic doses, if fentanyl is added, it can cause an overdose.)  Oxycotin came out with the warning that it was high risk for abuse when crushed & when doctors didn't read the drug info & adequately screen their patients, therefore having patients with pre existing substance abuse issues abusing them, they added a coating to prevent this type of abuse. Those people then started using other drugs illegally that have fentanyl in them, which significantly increased the ODs that WEREN'T HAPPENING when they abused oxycotin alone. Even when abused, Oxycotin was safer than street drugs.

For people who don't know why oxycontin caused so many to become addicted... the drug was marketed as a non-addictive drug because it was to be taken every 12 hours, 2X per day, which was supposed to take the pain away but without giving the person a "high" feeling. In short order, it was found that the drug did not last 12 hours in everyone. In many people, it only lasted 8 hours and, for some, it was only 6 hours. Purdue knew about it -- emails have been found in which they are telling salespeople to ignore that data and keep selling on the big marketing claim of every 12 hours dosage. Because it did not last a full 12 hours for some, they were set up for a cycle -- the drug would wear off early and they would go through withdrawal as their pain returned before expected; then they would be craving the drug, waiting with bated breath for the time when they could take another pill to relieve the pain. Finally, they. take the drug and have "relief" from pain. So people were set up for a withdrawal, craving, relief cycle which is characteristic of addiction.  From what I read, the CEO's of the company had to pay $32,000 fines. They should have gone to jail just like a person who committed robbery to buy more oxycontin or the person who got caught with possession after they bought it illegally on the street or the person who held up the drug store to get more... all other crimes associated with oxycontin are punishable with jail time. Except for the a-holes who distributed the dang stuff!!! So wrong.

It's important to recognize the 'push-pull' aspect of the opioid crisis. While pharmaceutical companies were pushing the drugs, the declaration of pain as the "fifth vital sign" begun by Dr. James Campbell but then almost every 'quality of life' agency, pulled us physicians into a descending spiral of pain hyper-consciousness which interfered with our previous medical training and put the issue in the hands of activists. In the end, the pharmaceutical companies were appropriately blamed, but the activists remain untouched to this day. I rarely prescribe narcotics to outpatients without a malignancy or a pain consult, but many physicians were essentially shamed into overprescribing by this onslaught of activism.

For the legal minded, it's called "piercing the corporate veil".  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piercing_the_corporate_veil  It's basically very hard for prosecutors to do.  Only in a few specific cases, like pollution, some safety things, or not paying employees.  The rules are also very state-based (John O mentioned White Plains, NY).  So, it's the reverse of what you'd expect: instead of government being able to hold ppl accountable for any reason (except, maybe, with a exceptions), the government can only hold people accounting only for a few _very_ specific reasons.  Personally, this is one of the few reasons I'd like to bring back the death penalty.  Can you imagine a public hanging at the Superbowl half-time show??  (Cue George Carlin reference.). Addiction isn't the only serious problem involved with the opioid crisis. People with chronic pain or recurring conditions requiring powerful pain relievers have also suffered.  I hate taking pain relievers, mainly because most of them don't work. I have a documented high resistance to pain relievers and alcohol. Tylenol, ibuprofen, and aspirin might as well be sugar pills, for all the good they do. That said, there have been a handful of times in my life where I found temporary use of painkillers necessary in order to perform daily tasks, due to injuries. These days, I have an ongoing condition that occasionally requires the use of strong painkillers so that I can perform basic tasks. Unfortunately, every one of the 4 visits I've made to the local ER in the last 4-5 years has ended up in doctors and nurses treating me like an addict looking for a fix. The last visit, just last month, culminated in the on-call doctor giving me something I later found was an anti-psychotic (Haldol). Even though I showed up in the ER pouring cold sweat, delirious, and with my heart rhythm starting to act up due to the level of pain I was feeling, that doctor was convinced it was all in my head. Because of that, I suffered through three days of intense migraines and hallucinations, on top of the high amount of pain I already had.  This is the level of fear in the medical community that is keeping addicts from obtaining narcotic prescriptions, at the expense of those who need pain management.

G.K Chesterton in 1909 presciently addressed the Sackler family's bountiful philanthropic donations. "Philanthropy, as far as I can see, is rapidly becoming the recognisable mark of a wicked man. We have often sneered at the superstition and cowardice of the medieval barons who thought that giving lands to the Church would wipe out the memory of their raids or robberies; but modern capitalists seem to have exactly the same notion; with this not unimportant addition, that in the case of the capitalists the memory of the robberies is really wiped out. This, after all, seems to be the chief difference between the monks who took land and gave pardons and the charity organisers who take money and give praise: the difference is that the monks wrote down in their books and chronicles, "Received three hundred acres from a bad baron"; whereas the modern experts and editors record the three hundred acres and call him a good baron."

In the early aughts, JCAHO, an accrediting body for healthcare systems, wanted hospitals to change the culture of "withholding pain meds" from patients.  This became an issue due to the massive amount of complaints reported by patients, that their pain was under treated.  So, I, along with a few other nurses, learned to become "Pain Control" nurses.  While it is true that much of the program involved the increased use of NSAIDs on a scheduled basis, among other things, the MAIN point, was that providers were to medicate all patients based on THEIR subjective reporting of pain.  This lead to a LANDSLIDE of opiate prescribing.  In part, due to a JCAHO mission to "help" patients, while misunderstanding how this would play out, with so many patients at risk for abuse.  I cannot even begin to tell you the massive doses of oxycontin some patients were receiving prior to surgery . For example, 240 mg, every 6 hours...not even every 12 HOURS!!! So, there are multiple links in this chain...

To be honest, the woman who invented oxycontin isn't totally wrong.  There was good evidence to believe that a slow-release opioid would be advantageous for chronic pain sufferers and similar pain treatment.  In general, slow-release drugs are less prone to abuse.  It was the execution of the slow-release mechanism, which was easily tampered with and defeated, and the relentless marketing and lies to doctors and the FDA, as well as the willingness of doctors to play along, that turned oxycontin into a horror show.  Nothing was intrinsically wrong with the idea.
One of the saddest parts of all this is now it is incredibly difficult at tmes for legitimate pain patients to get effective meds. I had major abdominal surgery recently and the doctor tried to prescribe me tramadol for at home pain. Tramadol does next to nothing for severe pain. I had to actually call the surgeon in and talk to him, and luckily he agreed and perscribed me a short course of low level oxy, which is very effective for pain. Dr's are now terrified to prescribe legitimate meds for serious surgeries and conditions, and it can be rough for patients. It's a sad fact. Oxy is by far one of the most effective pain meds out there and it sucks what has happened through bad practices.

I'm not a linguist, haven't studied it properly, don't plan to get a degree or minor in it because a degree in history is enough wasted time and money for my tastes, but I do quite love linguistics, and I really don't like that some people may have this and English teachers as their only exposure to anything relating to linguistics, so allow me to informally but strongly say that uh, most of the linguistics community would probably like to disown that bitch.   Also, I'd just like to share some fun linguistics facts to show that linguistics can be a cool and worthwhile field of study when it isn't plagued by massively wealthy drug pushers:  Finnish, unlike the major languages of neighboring countries, comes from a language family completely unrelated to most European languages that originated with Asian nomadic tribes.   Most Chinese dialects are not mutually intelligible, and thus speakers often cannot understand each other when talking to each other. However, these dialects share exactly the same Chinese writing, and because that writing system operates through symbols rather than phonetic letters, all Chinese dialects can be read the same, and understood through writing.   Korea, before the rule of Sejong the Great, used a system of writing adapted to Chinese before that king had scribes create a new writing system, which is still in use in Korea today. As the writing system was made to promote literacy, it is exceptionally easy to learn, even to a complete outsider, especially when compared with Chinese writing.  Conlanging, the practice of creating new languages, complete with newly assembled systems of grammar and custom phonologies, is an art form with applications in worldbuilding for writing or as a hobby enjoyed by many.   If you would like to know more, I encourage you to look around! There's a wealth of information that will make you wonder exactly how your English classes wound up being so boring!

Please do an episode on taxes that need to be filed by American citizens who live abroad. The USA is the only country in the world that requires citizens who live abroad to still pay taxes to the USA. The result is that there are millions of people that still need to pay the IRS thousands of dollars in taxes, even though they cannot vote or have never even set foot in the US. These taxes are on top of the taxes that they need to pay in the country in which they live. Many US citizens who have never lived in the US aren't even aware that they need to file these taxes and get fined tens of thousands of dollars out of the blue. In the Netherlands, many citizens even had their Dutch bank account blocked because the IRS required more information. "So then just renounce your US citizenship, right?" Well, in order to do that, you first have to pay back all the fines that you still owe and then you have to pay an additional 2350 dollars on top of that. And all this trouble isn't even limited to the American citizens themselves... If you marry and American citizen living abroad, you will also have to hand over all your financial information to the IRS.

Uh‚Ä¶ linguists don‚Äôt have no problems with double negatives. You see, there is a thing called ‚Äúnegative concord‚Äù where certain words change based on if the sentence is negative or not, and one of the most common choices in the world is to just use the negative form. Take the Latvian phrase: ‚Äúes nekad nevienam neko neesmu bijis parƒÅdƒÅ‚Äù, which has four negatives in a row (the words that start with ‚Äúne¬≠‚Äì‚Äù). Take as well, in English you cannot say, ‚ÄúI have any books,‚Äù to mean the opposite of ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have any books,‚Äù the actual positive version is ‚ÄúI have some books.‚Äù But as well, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have some books,‚Äù sounds equally ungrammatical, because that‚Äôs not how the negative is formed in English.  So, whether you‚Äôre saying ‚Äúany‚Äù or ‚Äúno/none‚Äù, you‚Äôre still bringing in a new otherwise ungrammatical word to indicate that the rest of the sentence is negative.  Linguists aren‚Äôt just English majors that took things too far. We don‚Äôt really tell anyone how they should be speaking, we look at how native speakers actually are speaking, and figure out what rules exist that would cause such speech to be made.

Most news outlets don't cover the forgotten victims of the opioid crisis - chronic pain patients.   As a chronic pain patient who 24/7 has the feeling I'm being stabbed in the head unless I'm properly medicated (and even then, it's never less than a 6/10 pain) I'm so frustrated with the opioid crisis. Chronic pain patients are treated like criminals. We have our meds restricted or taken away, we submit to monthly drug tests, we have our pills counted, they made me choose between my mental health medication and my pain medication, etc. I have lost three people from my chronic pain support group to suicide because the doctors denied them their meds.  The majority of the opiate overdoses are heroin or fake pills bought that contain fentanyl. I hate that heroin and fentanyl OD's are lumped with legitimate prescription cases.  Please don't take from this that I blame the addicts or the doctors. While they aren't helping, I blame people like the Sacklers and lawmakers who profit off of this and who don't take the time to learn about all sides of this issue.  Don't keep punishing pain patients, trust me we're being punished enough...
